title: Finite Configuration
content: A finite configuration in ℝⁿ is simply a finite set of points. The Ramsey question asks which such configurations have the special property that they appear monochromatically in any coloring.

title: Congruent Copy
content: A congruent copy of configuration A is its image under an isometry—a distance-preserving map. This captures the intuition of 'same shape and size' but possibly rotated, reflected, or translated.

title: k-Coloring
content: A k-coloring assigns one of k colors to every point in Euclidean space. The Ramsey property requires finding monochromatic copies no matter how this coloring is chosen.

title: IsRamsey Predicate
content: The central definition: a set is Ramsey if for any number of colors, some high enough dimension guarantees a monochromatic copy. The dimension d depends on both the configuration and the number of colors.

title: Spherical Set
content: A set is spherical if all its points lie on the surface of some sphere—equidistant from a common center. This is a necessary geometric condition for being Ramsey.

title: Ramsey Implies Spherical
content: The EGMRSS theorem (1973): every Ramsey set must be spherical. The contrapositive is used in practice—to show a set is not Ramsey, exhibit that it's not spherical (like collinear points).

title: Graham's Conjecture
content: Graham conjectures the converse: every spherical set is Ramsey. If true, this would completely characterize Ramsey sets as exactly the spherical ones.

title: Subtransitive Set
content: A set is subtransitive if it embeds in a set where rotations act transitively. This algebraic condition may provide the key to characterizing Ramsey sets.

title: LRW Conjecture
content: The Leader-Russell-Walters conjecture (2012): a set is Ramsey if and only if it is subtransitive. This provides an alternative characterization to Graham's conjecture.

title: Rectangles are Ramsey
content: The vertices of any k-dimensional rectangle form a Ramsey set. This was one of the first non-trivial results in Euclidean Ramsey theory (EGMRSS 1973).

title: Simplices are Ramsey
content: Every non-degenerate simplex (k+1 affinely independent points) is Ramsey. Proved by Frankl and Rödl (1990) using partite methods.

title: Trapezoids are Ramsey
content: All trapezoids (4 points with two parallel sides) are Ramsey. Proved by Kříž (1992), extending the known families beyond simplices.

title: Regular Polygons are Ramsey
content: All regular polygons and polyhedra are Ramsey. Kříž (1991) used permutation group methods to establish this broad family.

title: Non-Spherical Not Ramsey
content: The contrapositive of EGMRSS: any non-spherical set cannot be Ramsey. This provides a tool for ruling out configurations—check if they lie on a sphere.

title: The Characterization Question
content: The main open problem: find a nice property P such that P(A) ⟺ IsRamsey(A). While we can trivially take P = IsRamsey, the goal is a geometrically meaningful characterization.
